Hey guys, the app that I am currently working on, has a facebook feed kind of structure. I have a `ListView` and each element of it is a Horizontal `RecyclerView`. The items of `RecyclerView` are cards which contain images and some meta-data. So when this screen starts, there are 4 calls to `getView()` for 4 cards, because, at any instant 2 cards in a `RecyclerView` are visible and also top 2 `RecyclerView`s are visible in the beginning, thus 4 cards and 4 calls to `getView()`.
The problem is that when I scroll the list vertically, there is little lag/jitter
<@U0ESBF4AV>: nice! : )
Is there any way to make the scrolling lag free?
<@U0HJX4F9V>: One question how you are handling image loading in each card?
<@U0HJX4F9V>: probably by flattening the view hierarchy
I am using fresco library
a) don’t use fresco
b) please don’t use fresco
I tried flattening as much as I could
c) don’t use anything done by facebook
I have an similar feature on my app for ibm
<@U0548MM6B>: why?  I think it is awesome
LOL
<@U0HJX4F9V>:  custom views and drawing?
it works by taking up memory which is NOT SUPPOSED to be taken
earlier I was using Picasso and after a while, I will get OOM exceptions
if an app on your mac touched memory which shouldn’t be touched, would you use it?
use glide
<@U0HJX4F9V>: on my app im using universal image loader.
UIL is also good if you need customization which seems you do need
see, I don’t have any problem switching the library. But I don’t think any library is the problem here

i'm pretty sure i've identified memory leaks in my app but i have no idea how to fix them :sweat:
heap dump is showing a lot more ViewHolders and model objects than is being used in my view

if you have data for your current fragment cached in your presenter and you navigate to another fragment with a different presenter, data etc, but the old fragment is in your back stack, would the data ever get GC'd?
or is it common practice to dereference the data cache when you navigate away, then if the user navigates back, restore it?
depends, do you have references to views/context
naw, my presenter just keeps a reference back to the fragment for making updates to the view of course
fragment holds all of the references to view-related stuff
but if there's no limit on the size of the back stack, the fragments would stay in memory forever right?
hmm, it seems if i comment all of my .addToBackstack() calls, stuff gets GC'd fine. I think I need to play around with the memory profiling tool a little more to get a better understanding
Does anyone know why ParseException must be caught, but NumberFormatException doesn’t?
<@U0CHUGUDN>: you mean why it’s from point of Design or the compiler behavior?
compiler
ie why can I get away with not catching NFE but parseException I have to basically convert myself and turn it into a NFE
NFEs are coming from Double.parseDouble(). I have a custom method that uses the NumberFormat class , and those throw parse Exceptions

Because in Java you have 2 types of exceptions: 

1. Checked — if exception extends `Exception` it has to be `try-catched` 
2. Unchecked — if exception extends `RuntimeException` it doesn’t have to be `try-catched`
ah okay. thank you
it’s just part of Java language specification
and a lot of developers hate checked exceptions, though it’s just a problem of desing
In giant projects I’m sure it has it’s uses, even if it is a huge pain in the ass
thanks again
they really aren’t a pain in the ass
the only people it seems to bother are the developers that just want to ‘hack something real fast'
<— guilty
welp :stuck_out_tongue: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
<@U055GGAHS>: yeah, same thoughts from me. Though sometimes they’re just used wrong, like `UnsupportedEncodingException`, etc
yea
my favorite example of seriously messing shit up by just hacking it out is the android usb layer which in the case of a usb device returning an error.. you can not clear it no matter what
:thumbsup:

<@U0546QERR>: keep in mind just because there are extra view holders and such doesn’t mean memory leak. RecyclerView scraps the view holders but it doesn’t gc them it keeps them in scrap for recycling. If you force GC does it remove them?

Standard recyclerview, recyclerview.viewholder, recyclerview.adapter doesn’t have any memory leaks you should be fine (unless there’s some crazy thing like hundreds of viewholders or something in memory and they don’t gc when you force a gc call)
unless you are doing something crazy, recyclerview usually isn’t referencing a *lot* of memory anyways
have you tried running leak canary?

Yeah, obviously if you extend and muck with the internals, or make your own RecyclerView.Recycler implementation or something, then you could possibly introduce issues, but with standard components the mem usage should be small.

<@U055GGAHS>: okay I think I need to reconsider my app's navigation given my recent discovery about the fragment back stack. you can navigate to any fragment from anywhere in my app using the navigation drawer and i've just been adding fragments to the back stack each time, to simulate how you would navigate in a web browser
but if the fragment instance is retained every time then my data is just going to keep piling up

yeah so if I stop adding fragments to the back stack, everything seems to be GCing fine. but the memory allocation to my app still increases gradually with use... seems like it's coming from okhttp and picasso. will have to investigate why that's happening but at least the number of objects from my app's package is staying constant
